title: 112_s1245
content: The "Near East and South Central Asia Religious Freedom Act of 2011" allows for the appointment of a Special Envoy to promote religious freedom of minorities in the specified regions. The Special Envoy must be a distinguished individual in the field of human rights and religious freedom. The Special Envoy appointed under the "Near East and South Central Asia Religious Freedom Act of 2011" is tasked with promoting religious freedom, denouncing violations, monitoring intolerance, addressing the needs of minority communities, and working with foreign governments in the specified regions. The Special Envoy appointed under the "Near East and South Central Asia Religious Freedom Act of 2011" works with foreign governments to address discriminatory laws towards religious minority communities in the specified regions. They also assist in preparing reports on the extent of religious freedom for minorities in these countries. The Special Envoy appointed under the "Near East and South Central Asia Religious Freedom Act of 2011" coordinates with relevant agencies to address discriminatory laws towards religious minorities in the specified regions. The Special Envoy is authorized to represent the US in matters related to religious freedom in the Near East and South Central Asia, including contacts with foreign governments and participation in relevant multilateral conferences. The Special Envoy authorized to consult with organizations, receive funding for staff and investigations, and travel for the Act's provisions. The Act defines "countries of the Near East" as including Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Iraq, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, Libya, Morocco, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Syria, Tunisia, United Arab Emirates, Yemen, West Bank, and Gaza. It also defines "countries of South Central Asia" as Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan, Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan.
